Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts that show where you are. The website warned that when you say, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are also telling many people where you are, including some you might not want to meet. This shows that sharing everything online can have negative effects. 

The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a large audience, which can seem exciting. However, we often realize too late that sharing too much can be risky. It can feel overwhelming, but there is hope. A long time ago, some early internet users, known as bloggers, explored these risks. They faced many challenges, like losing jobs and friends, before social media became popular. 

One of these early bloggers was Justin Hall. In January 1994, he started sharing his life online when the web was mostly used by students and scientists. He created a personal website filled with stories, photos, and art. In 1996, he began a daily blog, attracting many readers who were interested in his adventurous life. Hall was open about everything, and his blog was both bold and artistic. 

However, one day, visitors found his homepage replaced by a video called Dark Night. Hall shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, his partner told him to choose between the blog and the relationship. Hall chose to remove the blog, feeling that sharing his life online made people distrust him. 

In 2002, another blogger named Heather Armstrong wrote a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job, but one day, a coworker shared her blog with their bosses, including some she had made fun of. This led to her losing her job. 

Experts say this is an example of the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online that they wouldn’t say in person. However, our online lives are connected to our real lives, and pretending they are separate can lead to serious mistakes. 

Armstrong’s story had a happy ending. After taking a break from blogging, she got married and started a new blog about her family. Now, she is successful as a "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned an important lesson: the internet lets us say anything, but that doesn’t mean we should.

A while ago, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called *What the Bleep Do We Know?* This film mixes documentary and drama to show that there is a lot we do not understand about our universe. Scientists can sometimes be a bit proud, but even the most confident physicist would not say they know everything about the universe. However, some scientists felt it was important to warn the public about the film, calling it things like “atrocious” and “very dangerous.” This made me curious to see the movie.

At first, I did not understand why there was so much excitement about it. Some scientists made simple statements about how new discoveries show that the universe is stranger than we thought. But when the film talked about some of these discoveries, I began to understand the excitement. One claim was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard before that a Japanese researcher showed that the shape of a water molecule could change based on the thoughts of people nearby. However, the movie only showed pictures of ice crystals that looked beautiful when someone was happy and ugly when someone was in a bad mood. Many people find this kind of evidence convincing, but scientists usually respond with skepticism.

I understand their reaction. The idea that water can be influenced by thoughts is amazing and could mean there are new forces in the universe. But before we believe it, we need good proof that this effect is real. Pretty pictures of crystals are not enough. The real issue is that the movie’s claims were not strange enough. For example, water molecules might have properties linked to a mysterious energy that is causing the universe to expand. This idea is supported by many years of research in labs and observatories around the world.

In fact, scientists are making discoveries that show the universe is stranger than we ever thought. Astronomers have found that the universe is made of an unknown type of matter and is pushed by a mysterious force called “dark energy.” Other discoveries are also surprising. Neuroscientists have found that our awareness of events happens about half a second after they actually occur, but we do not notice this delay because our brains edit it out. Anthropologists believe they have found where modern humans first appeared and how they spread across the world. Some theorists even suggest there are connections between life on Earth and the design of the universe.

Despite what some people think, science is not finished. In fact, we seem to know less than we thought. Many natural events may never be fully understood. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty show that there are limits to what we can know. Some of the best theoretical physicists are trying to create a “Theory of Everything” that would explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. Overall, many of us believe that the universe can be described in one word: incredible.

To put it simply, I find writing novels difficult, but writing short stories is a joy. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, while writing a short story is more like planting a garden. Both types of writing help each other, creating a beautiful landscape that I love. The trees provide shade, and the wind makes the leaves rustle, sometimes turning them a bright gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and their colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing us the change of seasons.

Since I started my career as a fiction writer, I have often switched between writing novels and short stories. My routine is this: after finishing a novel, I want to write short stories. Once I complete a group of short stories, I feel ready to focus on a novel again. I never write short stories while working on a novel, and I don’t write a novel while working on short stories. This is because each type of writing uses different parts of my brain, and it takes time to switch from one to the other.

I began my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I started writing short stories. I didn’t know much about writing short stories back then, so it was challenging, but I found it very memorable. I felt my fictional world expand, and readers seemed to enjoy this new side of me as a writer. One of my early stories, “Breaking Waves,” was included in my first collection, Tales from Abroad. This was my beginning as a short-story writer.

One of the best things about writing short stories is that they don’t take long to finish. Usually, it takes me about a week to write a short story (though I can spend a lot of time revising it). This is different from the long time and effort needed to write a novel, which can take a year or two. When I write a novel, it can feel like it goes on forever, and I sometimes wonder if I will finish. So, writing short stories is a nice change for me.

Another great thing about short stories is that you can create them from the smallest ideas – a thought, a word, or an image. It often feels like jazz improvisation, where the story takes me where it wants to go. Plus, with short stories, you don’t have to worry about failing. If an idea doesn’t work out, you can just move on and remind yourself that not every story can be perfect. Even famous writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t write a masterpiece every time. This gives me comfort. You can learn from your mistakes and use that knowledge in your next story.

When I write novels, I try to learn from both my successes and failures in writing short stories. In this way, short stories are like a testing ground for me as a novelist. It is hard to experiment in the same way within a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be even more difficult for me. My short stories are like soft shadows I have left in the world, and I remember exactly where I placed each one and how I felt when I did. Short stories are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy as a writer to share these personal feelings with my readers.

At its core, science is closely related to philosophy, but it also helps us solve real problems, like curing diseases. Science has made our lives easier, but it can also create risks. It tries to understand everything from tiny atoms to the vast universe. Science influences many areas, including poetry, politics, and philosophy. Sometimes, its beauty is only seen by those who study it deeply, and its dangers are often misunderstood. People have different opinions about how important science is, and its mistakes are sometimes ignored or exaggerated.

The history of science is full of disagreements. Old ideas are often changed or replaced by new ones. Just like in music, new ideas can be laughed at before they become accepted. Scientists can be jealous or angry, and conflicts are common in scientific history. This book will show how scientific ideas have changed not just science, but also how we think about many things. While science has practical uses, we will focus more on the ideas themselves, appreciating their beauty and being ready to question them. We must remember that human understanding has limits.

Science is always changing. There is always a scientist who is proving another scientist wrong. Most of the time, these changes do not disturb society too much. However, sometimes, big changes challenge our established beliefs. For example, in the 1600s, science described the universe as a giant clock. Now, physics has raised questions about this view, showing that our observations can change what we see and that we do not fully understand our basic ideas.

Some people think that the changing nature of science means it cannot explain the universe. However, changes in science usually help us understand and predict nature better. For instance, Isaac Newton explained more than the ancient Greek thinker Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained even more than Newton. Science may make mistakes, but it keeps moving forward. 

At the end of the 1800s, many physicists thought there was not much left to discover. Then, new ideas like radioactivity, X-rays, and quantum mechanics changed everything. Biology has also made many discoveries. Today, some people believe we are close to finding a complete theory that explains everything about the universe. 

Science is not just a fun activity. In the last 200 years, we have gone from simply observing nature to controlling it in some ways. Sometimes, we have upset the balance of nature without fully understanding the consequences. It is important for everyone, not just scientists, to understand scientific advances because they will shape the future for our children. Science is now a key part of how we think about and shape our future. The decisions we make based on science can affect everything from government budgets to the health of future generations and the survival of life on Earth.

From around 2015, after many years of growth, big publishers started to say that ebook sales had stopped growing or even decreased in some cases. This raised new doubts about the future of ebooks in the publishing industry. One publishing executive even said that the excitement about ebooks may have led to bad investments, making his company lose faith in the value of printed books. Even though it seems clear that ebooks and printed books can exist together, people still ask if ebooks will replace printed books. Whether people want to predict this or deny it, the idea of books disappearing continues to spark our imagination and create strong discussions. 

Why is this idea so strong? Why do we see the relationship between ebooks and printed books as a fight, even when evidence shows they can coexist? The answers to these questions go beyond ebooks and reveal our mixed feelings of excitement and fear about change and new technology. In my research, I have shown that the idea of one type of media replacing another often happens when new technologies are introduced. For example, when television was invented, many thought radio would disappear. But radio survived by finding new ways to be used, like listening in cars or at work. 

The idea that books might disappear is not new either. In 1894, people thought that the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This pattern has happened many times. Movies, radio, television, hyperlinks, and smartphones have all been said to threaten printed books at different times. Some people believed that the end of books would lead to a decline in culture, while others thought ebooks would create a better future. 

The idea of books disappearing often comes up during times of technological change. This idea reflects our hopes and fears about new technology. We form emotional connections with different types of media as they become important in our lives. Many studies show that we can feel close to objects like books, televisions, and computers, even naming our cars or getting frustrated with our laptops. So, when a new technology, like e-readers, appears, it changes our relationship with something we have grown attached to. As technology advances, we often miss what we used to know. This is why industries develop around older products and technologies. 

For example, when the printing press was introduced in 15th-century Europe, people started to look for original manuscripts. The change from silent to sound movies in the 1920s made people nostalgic for the older style. The same happened when photography changed from analog to digital and from vinyl records to CDs. E-readers have also made people appreciate the physical qualities of printed books, even their smell. This should comfort those who worry about printed books disappearing. 

However, the idea of disappearing media will continue to be an interesting story about how technology changes our lives and our fear of change. One way we deal with change is by using familiar stories, like those of tragedy and endings. The story of the death of the book is easy to remember and share. It reflects both our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our familiar world and ourselves.

For a year and a half, I woke up every weekday at 5:30 in the morning. I brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how some of the greatest thinkers of the last four hundred years managed their time. I wanted to understand how they organized their days to be creative and productive. By writing about their daily lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I hoped to show a different side of their personalities and careers. 

The French writer Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, “Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.” I believe it’s also important to know what time you eat and if you take a nap afterward. This book is not just about the final work of these creative people; it looks at their daily habits. It is also personal because I face similar questions in my life: How can you do meaningful creative work while making a living? Is it better to focus completely on one project or to work a little each day? When there isn’t enough time, do you have to give up things like sleep or a clean house, or can you learn to do more in less time?

I don’t have all the answers to these questions, but I have shared examples of how many successful people have dealt with similar challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas can be broken down into small daily actions and how daily habits can affect the work itself. The title of the book is Daily Rituals, but I really focused on people’s routines. Routines can seem boring, but they can also help us use our time, willpower, and optimism better. A good routine can help us stay focused and avoid being influenced by our moods.

The psychologist William James believed that having good habits allows us to focus on more interesting things. Ironically, he struggled with procrastination and could not keep a regular schedule. My own procrastination helped me start this book. One Sunday afternoon, I was at my job at a small architecture magazine, trying to write a story that was due the next day. Instead of working, I found myself cleaning my desk and making coffee. I am a “morning person,” so I can focus well in the morning but not in the afternoon. To feel better about this, I started looking online for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories and thought it would be great to collect them. This led to the Daily Routines blog I started that day and now this book.

The blog was simple; I shared descriptions of people’s routines from biographies and articles. For the book, I gathered more detailed and researched information while keeping the variety of voices that made the blog interesting. I let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from their letters, diaries, and interviews. In some cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. I want to thank the many biographers, journalists, and scholars whose work helped me. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section for those who want to read more.

Howard became a palaeontologist because of a change in interest rates when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, said that their planned holiday to Spain was not possible anymore. Instead, they rented a small house on the English coast. One rainy August afternoon, Howard found an ammonite on the beach. He had always wanted to be a palaeontologist, and by the end of university, he knew what kind he wanted to be. He was interested in the very early history of life, not in dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. He studied small, ancient creatures found in grey rocks.

When he finished his doctoral thesis, he wondered if he would get a job. He believed in himself and knew he had good potential, but he also knew that hard work does not always lead to success. When a job opened at Tavistock College in London, he applied, but he did not expect much.

On the day of his interview, the professor who was supposed to lead the panel had a fight with his wife. He left home upset, crashed his car, and ended up in the hospital. The interview happened without him, and a colleague who did not like the professor took his place. This colleague helped Howard get the job, even though Howard did not know him well. At first, Howard was grateful, but later he learned that the situation was not as he thought. He was a little disappointed but was mostly happy to have the job and be able to do the work he loved.

Howard often thought about how organized his work life was compared to his personal life, which could be chaotic. Many people can affect your life, and sometimes a stranger can change everything. This happened to Howard when someone stole his briefcase with his lecture notes at a train station. Angry, he went back to college, called to postpone his lecture, and reported the theft. After that, he went for coffee and met a colleague who was with a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. 

During this meeting, Howard learned about a new collection of fossils that needed to be studied. This could be his biggest challenge and help his career. Because of the theft, he changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students on a trip to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.

Charles Spence is a professor at Oxford University in the UK, and he is not picky about food. He even has ice cream made from bee larvae at home. Although they look like maggots, they taste a bit like nuts and flowers. Spence and his team are trying to make eating bugs more acceptable. He studies how our senses work together to create the flavors we taste. This research affects what we eat and drink, from big food companies to fancy restaurant menus.

Spence's book, The Perfect Meal, co-written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, shares interesting facts about food. For example, did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant usually enjoys their meal the most? Also, we eat about 35% more food when we are with one other person, and 75% more when we are with three people.

Spence's lab in Oxford is simple and not very modern. It has soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work with chefs who cannot pay for research. Much of his work is funded by a large food company. In the past, university research funded by companies was not seen as serious, but now it is important for universities to show their work has an impact.

Spence helps food brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. This is important for keeping customers healthy. Many companies make these changes slowly so that customers do not notice. Spence found that when people know about these changes, they focus more on the taste and often do not like it as much.

Spence met famous chef Heston Blumenthal while working on a project for a food company. At that time, people thought mixing science and food was strange, but Spence believed it was important. Together, they created a dish called "Sound of the Sea," which uses sound to enhance the dining experience. Spence has discovered that different sounds can change how we taste food. For example, high-pitched music can make food taste sweeter, while low sounds can make it taste bitter.

Soon, an airline will match music with the food served to passengers. Last year, a well-known brand released an app that played music while ice cream melted, but they did not match the music to the taste, which is often the case.

At home, Spence has unique dinner parties. Once, they ate rabbit with the fur around the cutlery. Another time, they used remote-controlled lights during dinner. They have even tested different drinks with sounds to see how it affects taste. For Spence, home, sweet shops, food events, and conferences are all part of his research.

Our brains are working harder than ever. We are bombarded with facts, false information, and rumors that we must sort through to find what is important and what we can ignore. At the same time, we are doing more things ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents booked our flights and salespeople helped us in stores. Now, we do most of these tasks on our own. We are trying to manage many responsibilities, like our families, jobs, hobbies, and favorite TV shows, all while using our smartphones. These devices help us fill every free moment with activities. 

However, there is a problem. Even though we think we are multitasking—doing many things at once—this is actually a misleading idea. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, explains that our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are really just switching quickly between tasks. Each time we switch, it costs us mental energy. So, we are not like expert jugglers; we are more like beginners trying to keep many plates spinning, worried that one will fall.

Even though we believe we are getting a lot done, multitasking makes us less efficient. It can increase stress hormones in our bodies, which can lead to confusion and unclear thinking. Multitasking also makes our brains crave constant stimulation, which can distract us easily. The part of our brain that helps us focus can be easily pulled away by new things, just like shiny objects attract babies.

Having the chance to multitask can hurt our ability to think clearly. Glenn Wilson, a psychology professor, found that trying to focus on a task while seeing an unread email can lower our IQ by almost 10 points. He showed that the mental loss from multitasking is even worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, a neuroscientist at Stanford, discovered that learning while multitasking can send information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework while watching TV, the information may not be stored properly, making it harder to remember later.

Multitasking also involves making decisions, like whether to reply to a text or ignore it. Making decisions is tough on our brains, and small decisions can use as much mental energy as big ones. After making many small choices, we can end up making poor decisions about important matters.

In discussions about information overload, email is often mentioned as a problem. It’s not that email itself is bad, but the huge amount of messages we receive can be overwhelming. When a 10-year-old boy was asked what his father does, he said, “He answers emails.” His father agreed that this is quite true. We feel we must respond to emails, but it often feels impossible to do that and accomplish anything else.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right position to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people thought these questions were not important. Animals had behaviors, and science studied those behaviors and their results. The idea that animals have thoughts, feelings, and morals was seen as silly. But this has started to change. Research on bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to explore animal emotions. This change has reached popular science books, like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". This has started a debate that may never be fully answered: do animals have consciousness? This debate leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong that guides their actions? 

In a recent experiment with cows, those that opened a locked gate to get food showed more happiness by jumping and kicking than those that had the gate opened for them. If cows enjoy solving problems, what does this mean for how we raise and eat beef? While the observations are clear, people disagree on what they mean. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, who wrote "Second Nature," believes we should stop eating meat. He thinks we are close to a big change in how we think about ethics, similar to the end of slavery. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, believes we should rethink how we understand animal thinking. He says animals likely have a simpler understanding of the world than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should not project human feelings onto animals. These three views may never agree because the main issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Since it is very hard to define consciousness, can we ever really know what it is like to be a bat, or a bat helping another bat?

Balcombe describes an important experiment he did that suggests starlings, a type of bird, can feel depressed. In a study at Newcastle University, starlings were divided into two groups. One group lived in nice cages with plenty of space and water, while the other group lived in small, empty cages. At first, both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid unpleasant worms from another. But when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the starlings in the nice cages would eat. Balcombe concluded that living in a bad cage made the starlings feel negative about life. Balcombe, who has worked with animal rights groups, has a strong opinion. He says, “We look back with disgust at a time of racism. One day, we will feel the same about how we view animals. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.” 

If Balcombe were the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning shares similar ideas. Manning has written a textbook called "An Introduction to Animal Behaviour." He says, “What we are seeing is a swing in ideas. In the early 20th century, some people thought animals thought just like us, and then there was a reaction against that. Now we are moving back to the idea that animals have thoughts. But this is a very debated topic, and we should be careful about listening to academics with strong personal opinions.”

Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear more deeply. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation in the U.K., believes that arguing can help us find the truth. While technology helps us store and process information, there are worries that it also makes it harder for us to think deeply about complex problems. West points out that we are often surrounded by poor quality thinking and popular opinions that can confuse us. Even though we have more information than ever, it does not always lead to better knowledge or decisions. 

According to the National Endowment for the Arts, fewer people are reading literature, and this decline is speeding up. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, thinks that focusing more on visual media, like videos and games, may hurt our critical thinking skills. She says that people are multitasking and not concentrating on one thing as much as before. However, we still do not have a clear answer on how technology affects critical thinking. 

Technology has changed how we think, and it can have both positive and negative effects. For example, some computer games can help improve critical thinking, while reading online can enhance our ability to analyze information. Greenfield has studied how learning and technology interact and found that reading helps develop imagination and critical thinking, while visual media like video games and TV do not engage our imagination in the same way. 

However, she also found that visual media can help with some types of information processing. Unfortunately, many visual media do not give us time to think or reflect. This can lead to young people not reaching their full potential. 

How society views technology affects how we think about critical thinking. James Paul Gee, a professor of educational psychology, argues that video games can actually be good for learning. He says that while many believe video games are bad for kids, they can also be a great tool for education. Some games, like Sim City and Civilization, teach important skills like decision-making and analysis in a fun way. These games allow players to explore ideas that they might not be able to in real life. 

In today’s digital world, as reading and math scores go down, it is important to understand how technology affects our thinking and analysis.

When Matthew Crawford is not thinking and writing about how we should live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He chose this job after he became unhappy with working in an office and for social policy organizations. His first book was about the good things about manual jobs. His latest book talks about how to deal with modern life. He got the idea for this book when he was shopping and saw advertisements on the credit card machine while he was entering his pin number. Crawford realized that it is becoming harder to avoid things that demand our attention. What we want to think about at any moment is personal, but we often cannot choose this for ourselves because of things we do not notice. It is getting harder to think or remember conversations we’ve had. Because everyone wants to avoid being interrupted, we often stop talking to strangers. Crawford says, “We see the world through things that are made for us, like video games and apps on our phones.” These things reflect our desires and can take over our lives.

Crawford is not the only one who is worried. Many office workers complain about emails all day and then spend their free time checking emails. Studies show that our attention can wander if a phone is just sitting on the table. Many of us have felt bored at dinner, wanting to check our phones. There is no scientific proof yet that our attention spans have changed, but people have worried about this since the telegraph was invented in 1837. It is clear that we are more aware of other things we could be doing. Some people think this problem is caused by technology, but Crawford believes that technology has made it easier for us to focus on ourselves. With so many choices, it is hard to control ourselves, and this affects our social lives. We often prefer to send a text message instead of talking to someone face-to-face. Crawford argues that by only interacting with screens instead of real people, we risk losing important connections in our society.

He gives an example from his gym. There used to be one music player in the middle of the room that everyone could use. People had different music tastes, which sometimes caused tension. Now, people listen to their own music with earbuds. “The gym used to be a social place, but it has lost that feeling,” he says. Real connections with others often happen when there is some conflict, like discussing different music tastes.

Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we need to control noise and distractions in public spaces. More importantly, he believes we should engage in skilled activities to connect with the world in a more satisfying way. He mentions cooks, ice-hockey players, and motorcycle racers as examples of people who deal with real things. No video game can replace the feeling of a hockey puck on ice or the gravel under your tires when you ride fast. These people use their good judgment and manage their surroundings. “When you engage with the world this way, fake experiences seem less important than real ones,” he says. “They lose some of their power.”

This does not mean everyone should become a chef; it is important to find ways to use your judgment. There are many benefits beyond job satisfaction. Constantly fighting distractions can be tiring and make it harder to focus on what is important. On the other hand, paying attention to one thing can help you pay attention to other things too.

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question in small talk, and we often define ourselves by our jobs. However, if you are a philosopher like me, it can be a bit tricky. Saying you are a philosopher can sound a bit showy. It’s better to say you study or teach philosophy. Many people think that calling yourself a philosopher means you know some special truth, but that’s not true. Philosophers are just like everyone else.

One reason people have this idea about philosophers is that they often judge what others do and celebrate thinking. The Greek philosopher Aristotle believed that a life spent thinking deeply was the best kind of life. While not all modern philosophers agree, philosophy is still seen as connected to deep thinking. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that "the unexamined life is not worth living." This means that just going along with what everyone else thinks can make life less satisfying. 

Thinking about our lives helps us make our own choices. However, you don’t need to read many difficult philosophical books or live a life away from society to examine your life. It just means paying more attention to your daily experiences to see if they are meaningful. The examined life is practical and should be shared because it is important for a good life.

Another reason people misunderstand philosophers is that academic philosophy has become more separate from everyday life, especially for those who don’t have formal training. This is not only the philosophers' fault; universities often focus on expensive journals and evaluations, making it hard for philosophers to share their ideas with anyone outside their small group of experts. Because of this, philosophy can seem far away from real life. 

Many philosophers used to challenge this view, but now some accept it. The academic world has created a situation where philosophers are isolated. As philosophy has become more focused on specific debates, it has become harder for those outside the field to understand. In some cases, philosophy has even pulled away from society.

I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because I work in ethics, which is about judging human actions. Recently, I feel this title doesn’t fully describe my work because ethics is often linked to formal rules and laws. There is a new area in philosophy called applied ethics, which looks at whether certain social practices are fair. The job of an ethicist today is to decide if an action is ethical or acceptable. These are important questions that I think about often.

A typical discussion might start by asking if downloading movies illegally is wrong (it is) and then move on to bigger questions about responsibility, our views on art, and how consumerism affects us. Philosophy can help people think more deeply about the actions and behaviors that shape their lives. Sometimes we might find out something we already knew; other times, we may realize our beliefs are hard to defend. Either way, by examining these ideas, we can do something good for everyone.

**Simplified Text:**

People who love food, like foodies and chefs, might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. However, in history, discussions about food have often been less important than other philosophical topics. When philosophers talk about eating, they usually use it as a way to discuss something else, like gaining knowledge. Sometimes, conversations about food seem to be about food, but they often explore deeper ideas that are not directly related.

One interesting philosopher is Epicurus, who believed in seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in many areas of life. His name is now often connected with enjoying food and drink. You can see his name in restaurants, food shops, and recipe websites. These businesses likely hope to attract customers by linking their products to famous philosophers.

Food is also a social and cultural experience. The food we eat comes from history and is shared with our communities. These communities help us find people to eat with and provide the means to grow and distribute food. We interact with food more than with any other product, making it a clear topic for philosophical discussion.

Once food is ready, critics start to talk and write about it. But why do they have such a special role? One philosopher pointed out that tasting food is not a special skill; food critics are just better at describing flavors. This area has not been studied much, as most research on perception has focused on sight. This needs to change.

Another important part of food is its beauty. We often talk about art and music being beautiful, but we don’t usually talk about the taste of food in the same way. Some philosophers believe that, with the growth of modern cooking, food deserves to be discussed as art, like sculpture or poetry. However, food is eaten and gone after we enjoy it, unlike art that we can keep and appreciate over time. This makes it hard to say that food can be considered beautiful in the same way.

There are also many ethical questions about food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? Our answers often show our beliefs about ethics. Philosophers will always question why we choose what we do, and discussing these issues is important.

Cooking at home and in restaurants can be very different. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests because of their personal relationships. In a home kitchen, everyone shares food and time together. In contrast, professional cooks have duties to their employers and the food itself. Their kitchens are not open to everyone, and their relationships are more like colleagues than friends.

A recent essay called "Diplomacy of the Dish" looks at how food and dining can help connect different cultures. This happens in two ways: first, we can learn to appreciate other cultures by enjoying their food; second, we can build friendships with people from other cultures by sharing meals. This practice has a long history in international relations. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories that make this part of food philosophy come alive for readers.

Rob Daviau is a game designer from the US who creates ‘legacy’ board games. He felt that the traditional board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore, so he thought about how board games could change. He wondered if they could have a story and if choices made in one game could affect future games. He took a classic game called Risk and made a new version called Risk Legacy. In this game, decisions made during play have lasting effects. Players might have to tear up cards, mark the board, or open new packets with different rules at important moments. The game is played over several sessions, and players can hold grudges that affect the game. Daviau said, “You could point to the board and say: ‘Right here! You did this!’”

Later, he worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players work together to cure diseases. His next project was a game called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very successful, SeaFall was seen as a big test for the legacy format because it was the first game that did not follow an earlier version. In SeaFall, players become sailors in the age of sail (16th to mid-19th century) and explore a new world. Designers of legacy games must think about all possible player choices to keep the story interesting. To do this, they use play-testers to see how the games work. Jaime Barriga, a play-tester for SeaFall, said, “It takes a lot of time. Sometimes the first few games are great, but then later games can have problems, and you have to fix everything.”

Legacy board games were not expected to become very popular. When Daviau was creating the idea, he thought it would only appeal to a small group of people. He said, “I thought I would be known as the guy who did this weird project.” However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He believes it is one of the biggest improvements in game design in years. He said, “It’s a new level of commitment, intensity, and excitement.” Another fan, Ben Hogg, said that the fun of a new adventure was more important than worrying about how long the game would last. He mentioned that people don’t usually watch the same movie twice in the cinema; they want a new experience. 

The legacy format is inspired by video games and popular TV shows. While in college, Daviau wanted to be a television writer but later moved into advertising and game design. Still, he loved telling stories. Matt Leacock, the creator of Pandemic, compared making a legacy game to writing a novel. He said, “You need to know how you want it to end and have a good idea of where to start, but you also need more than just an outline.” Daviau feels proud of his work but is curious to see how others will use the idea. He thinks gamers will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, the studio manager for SeaFall, believes the legacy format has changed how people think about board games.

One night not long ago, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He crawled across the floor and squeezed into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was exciting and was shared a lot online. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think that animals are similar to us. Octopuses are especially interesting because they are very smart and look very different from humans. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells for protection, and even play in clever ways.

Some scientists, like Dr. Frans de Waal, study animal intelligence. He believes that instead of thinking animals are not like us, we should recognize their human-like qualities. He has studied many years of research on animal intelligence and found that animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like remembering the past and the future, showing empathy, and understanding what others want.

In the past, people believed that animals were smart enough to be put on trial for crimes. Even Charles Darwin, who changed how we see our place in the world, said that the difference between human and animal minds is not so big. However, in the twentieth century, many scientists started to see animals as simple machines that only respond to rewards and punishments. This view became popular at the same time that humans were harming animal habitats and not caring for their welfare.

Now, Dr. de Waal thinks we are starting to understand that animal intelligence is more similar to human intelligence. He says that we are learning a lot about animals, especially with the help of the internet. He believes that the best tests for animal intelligence should consider the special skills of each species. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they are great at remembering where they hide their nuts.

In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might judge us by how well we can change the colors of our skin. If we failed, it might think we are not very smart.

Dr. de Waal is not completely sure that Inky really knew how to escape to the ocean. He points out that while some octopuses have escaped before, it might be too hopeful to think Inky planned his escape. However, he understands that stories like Inky's help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment with capuchin monkeys to see if they could feel envy. When some monkeys received cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers became very upset. This study was published in a scientific journal, but a short video of the experiment made people really believe the findings. This shows how our understanding of animal minds is still growing.

Robotics, once just a part of science fiction, is now changing our world in a big way. Robots have been used in car and factory production for many years, but experts believe we are about to see robots used in many more areas. They warn that many countries are not ready for this big change. 

Many people think that robots will take over most jobs in the next 50 years. However, about 80% of people believe their own jobs will still exist in the same way. This shows that we feel safe about our jobs, but we shouldn’t. Every industry will be affected by robots soon. For example, an Australian company called Fastbrick Robotics has created a robot named Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This job would take two human workers a whole day or more.

Another example is a robot called Tally, made by a company in San Francisco. Tally moves around supermarkets to check if products are in stock and correctly priced, instead of cleaning the aisles. 

Supporters of robots say that robots cannot fix or program themselves yet. This means new jobs will be created for skilled workers like technicians and programmers. However, some people worry that we should not forget the importance of human skills at work. They believe society is not ready for the changes that will come when robots take over some jobs.

Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots will change the workforce. His recent report says that in two years, one-third of robots will be smarter and able to work with other robots and humans safely. In three years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will create laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field will rise by at least 60%, but many jobs will still be unfilled because there aren’t enough skilled workers.

Zhang says that automation will affect lower-skilled workers, which is unfortunate. He believes these workers need to retrain themselves instead of waiting for the government to protect their jobs. People cannot expect to do the same job for their whole lives anymore.

New technologies will also create new types of robots for homes, which we have not seen before. These robots will be able to interact with us in more advanced ways, similar to those in science fiction. Zhang believes this is a great chance for companies, but it also brings challenges, like the need for new rules to keep us safe and protect our privacy.

With many jobs at risk and a global employment crisis coming, it is important to focus on education. Developed countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to stay competitive in the future.

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, once answered a reporter's question about why he wanted to climb Mount Everest by saying, "Because it’s there." This answer shows a common feeling: many people wonder why someone would take such a dangerous risk. Some might feel inspired by his words to follow their dreams, while others see climbing as just an adventure and a way to have fun.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called "Games that Climbers Play." He described seven different climbing activities, from playing on small rocks to climbing high mountains, each with its own rules. He believed that the way climbers approach a climb depends on the rules of the specific activity. Over the years, this idea has become popular in climbing discussions, from magazines to casual talks.

Many climbers love the feeling of freedom that climbing gives them. However, climbing can also feel very limiting. For example, being stuck in a tent during a storm is not what most people think of as freedom. This creates a contradiction in climbing. But some argue that having fewer choices can actually make life simpler and provide a different kind of freedom.

When asked "Why climb?", US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes that climbing is part of human nature. We are born to take on challenges and test our limits, even if it is risky. The joy we find in climbing is more about our biology than just logical thinking.

Another important idea comes from US academic Brian Treanor, who says that climbing can help us develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. While not all climbers show these qualities, Treanor believes they are especially important in today’s world, which often avoids risks. Climbing can help us grow and live better lives outside of climbing.

Some climbers believe that those who climb without help from others or technology must be very dedicated to succeed. Expert climbers Ebert and Robinson stirred some debate by saying that climbs done alone or without extra support deserve more recognition than those done with teams or special equipment, like bottled oxygen. This idea raised concerns that it might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.

We can also look at climbing from a different perspective. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "going with the flow." The physical effort, the focus while climbing, and the instinctive problem-solving are all key parts of the experience. Some argue that climbing is similar to techniques in Zen philosophy, which helps people find peace of mind. This gives us another idea to think about when we ask why people are attracted to climbing.

Over the last sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became very important in classical music. He was a serious person who studied and recorded many famous European piano works. He wrote and performed a lot, but he did not teach many students. People who knew him saw a fun side to him, but he rarely showed it during his concerts. His life was a strict routine of studying, traveling, and performing.

About four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked him for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take this request seriously. He had very few students and did not see a reason to start teaching now. He remembered a famous pianist who said, “You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.” However, he was impressed by Kit, who was about 14 years old. Brendel listened to him play and said, “He played very well and from memory. Then he gave me a CD of a recital where he played so beautifully that I thought, ‘I have to make time for him.’ It was a performance that took you from the first note to the last. It’s rare to find a musician with this kind of understanding and skill.”

As Brendel steps back from the public eye, Kit is starting to become more known. Brendel is careful, worried that Kit might burn out too quickly. Now 19, Kit is always busy, learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all while his mother watches over him. He also composes music. Brendel says, “This is very important. Learning to read music is easier when you try to write your own. I noticed that Kit has an amazing memory and can read music very well. He listens to his own playing and understands what I explain to him. When I tell him something to do in a piece, he can do it everywhere in that piece.”

Brendel becomes serious and says, “I don’t want to raise expectations. I get very upset when newspapers do this. One article called him the future great pianist of the 21st century, which is not good. It can cause problems. Like many talented young players, he can play some things very well, but he still needs time and experience for others. It would be unfair if a critic expected him to be perfect.”

Now at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed in his retirement. He explains, “When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by the time I was 50. When I turned 50, I felt I had done most of those things, but I still wanted to do more, so I continued. Even though I don’t have the same physical strength now, I still have many ideas in my mind and pieces I’ve never played. I don’t perform now, but I enjoy this new phase of my life.”

When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My grandad’s garden was by a river and sloped down to the water. You couldn’t get to the river, but you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I believed all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. 

Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic covering broken glass. At home, my father was often quiet. He had a sense of humor and liked to say funny phrases, like “It’s immaterial to me.” He didn’t have many dreams and left school without qualifications. He became a plumber, which he didn’t love. He wasn’t very ambitious, although he and my mother once thought about moving to Canada, but it didn’t happen. 

My father was good at fixing things around the house. He could build bookshelves and cupboards very well. My parents only moved house once, but my mother loved changing the furniture. Just when you got used to one chair, she would bring in another. The biggest change was when a piano arrived. I wanted to like it, but it made me nervous. I liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mother thought they were too fancy, and they disappeared while I was at school. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister took lessons instead. When I asked my mother why, she said, “You’d never have practiced.”

Of the places to explore – moors, woods, or the river – I always chose the river. I could imagine a different world there. With a fishing net over my shoulder, I would walk along the riverbank in old sandals. I looked for a good spot to take off my sandals and leave them with my picnic while I searched for fish to catch. After trying to keep the fish alive in the backyard, I had to return them to the water.

I wanted to leave school quickly, but it seemed impossible until one day my father said, “There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might like it.” In that moment, he surprised me. He might have preferred if I became a carpenter, but I believe he saw my love for gardening. Even though he didn’t like gardening himself, I think he noticed my passion for plants and flowers.

Lawrence MacEwen is crouching down on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am doing the same. A strong wind from the Atlantic is trying to blow us off the steep cliff at our feet and into the ocean below. Then, MacEwen’s sheepdog, Tie, comes close, and his owner gently pets him. The loud wind cannot make MacEwen uncomfortable on his island, where he feels at home. 

MacEwen is showing me around his neighborhood. He points to the north and shouts, “That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.” I see dark clouds pouring rain on Rum’s big mountains. “Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.” 

Suddenly, MacEwen says, “I have sheep to move,” as rain starts to come our way. We walk down the slopes, and he tells me more about the island: Volcanic Muck is three kilometers long and one and a half kilometers wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. 

While herding the sheep, Tie, the sheepdog, is not doing a good job. “Away to me, Tie. Away to me,” means the dog should go to the right, but he goes straight through the flock, causing confusion. “Tie,” MacEwen says sadly. “That will never do.” The dog looks ashamed. 

The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm; their son Colin manages the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby enjoy that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. “They go out the door and come back only when they’re hungry.” 

But living on the island has its challenges. For example, electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I see Mary preparing breakfast with a flashlight. I also have to deal with no mobile phone service. “You can get a signal on the hill,” Mary tells me. “Most people last a couple of days, then just put their phone away.” So I do the same. 

Everything on Muck feels surprising. Today, the boat brings some groceries and three musicians who come off carrying instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, and the islanders enjoy the music. 

That night, sitting by a warm fire while it rains outside, Lawrence tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. “Her father saw a small farm on the Isle of Soay in a newspaper and bought it without looking at it. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.” Did Jenny know how to run a farm? “She had good typing skills.” 

I go to bed listening to the rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, as almost all my food comes from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I carry it back through the village and give it to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is delicious. 

The next morning, I worry about my ferry ride to the next island. Many ferries had been canceled in the last two months because of rough seas. If my ferry does not come, I would be stuck on Muck for two more days, which I secretly wish for, phone or no phone.
