Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of cold Arctic landscapes, maybe because I was tired of the noise and crowds of London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a job as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm,' which they described as a beautiful but basic location with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I understood what I was getting into. "The hours are long, the conditions are tough, and the work is very physical," they said. I started packing right away.

November 6, London
On my flight, I stared at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names, but I felt distracted and nervous. I put the page down and looked out the window instead. It is said that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. But I felt like I was seeing winter moving south, with rivers freezing over.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta
The bus ride north was everything I hoped for. We drove through endless dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrived at the farm after dark, and as soon as I walked in, I was given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. "Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?" Anna asked. I followed the sound of barking, which grew louder as I reached the dog sheds. Three people were running back and forth, pulling the huskies out and getting them ready for sleds. The dogs were very excited, pulling against their ropes. I could barely introduce myself because everyone was too busy. I stood to the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone told me to "Get in!" and I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and we took off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta
I quickly learned how to be a husky guide, but first, I had to answer questions about what I could do. "Are you useful?" Anna asked. I was confused. I didn’t know if I was. After more questions, I realized I was not very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, I hadn’t done woodwork since school, and I had never chopped anything with an axe. "You do have a driving license?" someone asked. I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. But other tasks were complicated. Simple things like feeding and watering the dogs became hard in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, I was overwhelmed with instructions, and my muscles hurt from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw," I emailed my friends. "In the snow."

On that day, when Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters came to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was good enough to qualify for the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special treatment called emu oil, which Olympic gold medalist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help Radcliffe heal from an injury caused by a bike accident during training. Radcliffe said that she didn’t fully realize how big her achievement was at the time. Looking back, she understands it was a significant moment, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. She and her team decided not to set any limits on their performance, and their motto was "no limits."

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was also with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried that she might not be able to keep up her fast pace and might drop out of the race. Hartmann was angry about this concern, but he understood that someone who didn’t know how fit Radcliffe was might think it was risky to start so quickly.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to think about her time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers very quickly, but she managed to sprint the last distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time. Radcliffe thought, "I will come back and do it next year," and she really believed she could.

Unfortunately, that did not happen. After the race, everyone wanted to know how Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, helping her with daily training to support the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, "I have worked with 63 Olympic medalists, and no one could handle the pain like she could. She would make me work hard because I had to go deep into her muscles, and I would be in pain afterwards."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for a friendly greeting; Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour training session. Hartmann said, "Paula would push you to your limits, and that’s what made her so good." He spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became jealous.

When asked why no one has come close to her record, Radcliffe said, "I trained really hard, but there are more talented people out there." She thought someone like Mary Keitany, a two-time London marathon winner, might break her record. Radcliffe explained that some runners focus more on competing against each other than on improving themselves. She believed that her strong mental focus helped her push through the race without relaxing, always trying to run as hard as she could.

Radcliffe did not know it at the time, but that marathon was the best performance of her career. She would never run that fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. There was a lot of talk about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain, and I believed we had created a series that added something new to it. However, I worried if people would like a cooking show that included not just cooking techniques but also history and science. I watched the first episode feeling both happy and nervous. I didn’t need to worry. The show became very successful and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. 

In each project, I felt like I was on a journey, whether it was exploring the past, understanding cooking techniques, or learning about different cultures. I wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving travel and new experiences. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who makes golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent many years trying to reach their own idea of perfection.

Perfection is different for everyone. Choosing which dishes to include in the series was very difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was not included. I could imagine people asking, “Where is steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?” But after a long meeting, the TV team and I created a list that would please many people. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on their feelings, memories, and experiences.

Even though the book is called ‘Perfection’, I knew I wouldn’t say that the recipes were the best or final. I believed that by using my cooking skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, chefs, and customers, I could discover what makes these dishes special. The dictionary says ‘perfection’ means being perfect, but it also means improving through practice and trying new ideas until you create something unique.

The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen before. I was excited to learn about food and memories because I started my career in a similar way. Finding the best ingredients took me all over the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was using the wrong tomatoes and going to a dairy farm that did not meet our standards, so we had to stop filming there! While perfecting each recipe, I even hand-milked a cow and used dry ice to make ice cream, cooked chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burned my house down trying to make a real Neapolitan pizza.

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, went off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the engine. He looked at it for a long time with his hands in his pockets and a serious look on his face. “Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried. “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field was big and empty, just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was better to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So, I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything they talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound very sure. “Liar,” she said. I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought about it, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. 

John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind. They waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “It’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it got dark. Mum took out blankets and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said. 

Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind it with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we would get home now that our van had to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke good English. They talked about the music they were playing and their recent travels. 

“I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said. It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world. Because of this, she missed so much school that she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She was one of the lucky few chosen from thousands of applicants. At the party, her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to celebrate. Her little brother Gus dreamed about being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took Lucy out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself. Her mom had filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn’t want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought her mom just didn’t want to let her say no. Back then, Lucy believed that making waves was a bad thing, so she didn’t think about trying to get out of it.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in closer. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah,” Lucy replied. “How old are you?” he asked. “Fifteen,” she said. He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy didn’t mean to brag. It was hard to know when to share her achievements and when to keep quiet. “It’s just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying,” she explained. 

“Excuse me,” Liesel/Louisa said, looking away as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, messy hair, like many musicians, to show he was a cool music nerd. “Once, when I was about eight,” Lucy replied. He started to say something when Lucy's grandfather appeared beside her. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,” he said, pulling her away. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” 

“They're not the competition,” Lucy replied. “Everyone is the competition,” her grandfather insisted. He took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said. 

In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” Lucy liked that. She enjoyed being recognized, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from the kids at her old school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play a difficult piece by Rachmaninov. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

Text: "‘You spend too much time online. You need to go outside and enjoy the real world,’ said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I wanted to see what experts say about this. It’s quite interesting. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have a lot of real-life friends, feel like they belong, and are learning important skills for the digital world. Simon Miles, an expert on online safety, says ‘social networking is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do; they live in it. This isn’t good or bad – it depends on how you use it.’ 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media expert, says it’s like the youth clubs that parents used to go to. It helps teenagers share jokes and gossip, and it helps them grow away from their parents and deal with teenage problems. Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says: ‘Adolescence is a time when you ask, who am I? Social networking can help you find your identity. You can share your favorite music or sports, find what you like, and see that others have different opinions. Research shows that active social networkers are not more self-centered than those who don’t use social media.’ He adds that social media can help shy people: ‘Talking online can be easier than in person, and it helps you practice social skills in a safe way.’

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with special interests connect with others who like the same things. ‘If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social media group with similar interests, you can feel more connected and popular in a different way,’ he says. 

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: ‘Young people who find new interests online, join groups, and create their own content are really using social networks well.’ She thinks social networking is becoming a way to be creative: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites are helping photographers connect, learn, and share their work. ‘This can help you get a job in the future,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to sell and promote themselves – you need to know how it works to attract customers. For example, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on social networks, they could all be potential customers. If you connect all those networks, you have your customer base.’

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they grow up and start working, agrees Matthews. ‘One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create and share content. Working together is an important skill in the 21st century and helps you get a job in the digital world.’"

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a part of Canada. But my parents were not looking for a quiet time this summer. My dad decided to plan what he called the ultimate family bonding trip. He and my mom kept saying, “Not enough people do this anymore,” while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, “Maybe there’s a good reason for that!”

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. Still, I had some ideas to cope. With barely enough space left in the car, we started our “Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our big home for smaller places for the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we were getting into.

We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. The desert changed to mountains, and the days started to blend together, but each adventure was still special. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we noticed a strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next stop, we realized that the roads marked for Jeeps were best for Jeep drivers.

Every place we visited showed a mix of old and new. We got used to traffic from construction. We laughed when we saw the big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. On our way to Yellowstone National Park, we saw many wind farms and watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. We experienced “bear jams,” where traffic would stop to let bears cross, and we had a close encounter with a bear and a worried park ranger, which gave us unforgettable memories.

As we drove, life back home felt far away. Even the hotel we stayed in, which was old and had no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t take away our excitement. In return for these things, I got to see the most beautiful views I’ve ever seen. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, my family and I headed back south. My parents were right; you don’t need to go to a faraway place to find something amazing.

It was a little sad to be home again, but at least I didn’t fight with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our trip to look through. I knew that the best memories would be the unexpected and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy needed to finish her last year of school, so she would live at the college. She was happy because she got the best room, which had its own kitchen and study area. Amy also liked that she could use the Internet and phone for free. Jeff and Dahlia would check on Amy, even if she didn’t want them to.

Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only remembered a few happy times with Daisy and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not very excited, but Daisy was happy to have Rose with her. Rose didn’t know why her parents didn’t get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Because of this, Rose had spent her summers away from Daisy. The last time Rose saw her grandmother, she was only ten years old, but she remembered it fondly. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose expected to get many dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not a typical old lady; she seemed to go to more events than anyone else.

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But Rose wanted one thing: her independence. She wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission. She felt she could be trusted to do these things. She didn’t want to be reminded about homework or staying out late, and she didn’t want to be taken around by her grandmother. Daisy understood this. Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen phone with a video camera for emergencies only, which made Rose very happy. They all agreed to trust each other. Daisy would trust Rose to make good choices, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If either of them went too far, they would talk about it again.

Rose was not a wild child. Her few friends were similar, so her school reports were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be her last school before finishing. For Rose, it was a new beginning in her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first person to think she might write a novel. She said, “I thought writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed very challenging. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I should try this now.’” The novel she started at that age is now about to be published. 

Charlotte recently told her former teacher about her book, and the teacher was surprised. She had thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait to do something she was good at. 

It was a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a great achievement: it has a strong story and is full of action. Nothing about it, except for the age of the main character, shows that it was written by a teenager. 

A public relations representative was with us in case Charlotte needed help, but she didn’t. She is confident, smart, and steady, which keeps her from being overly confident. Charlotte understands that she is still young. When I asked her about the complex moral questions in her book, she said, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She laughed and added, “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I’m very wise. I just wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility.”

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often shown in books. She believes there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially. She found it frustrating to read about these types. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who are not inadequate in some way. Some writers give the impression that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience. This can hurt their self-confidence.”

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy authors, but their books almost made her stop writing. “My favorite fantasy writers explore deep topics about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to write like that to create a good book and if I was capable of it.” However, she found a helpful book called How Not to Write a Novel. “It says that if the reader starts to guess what will happen, the suspense is probably gone.”

Some might say that Charlotte’s parents, who are both journalists, helped her get her novel published. Her father knew someone in publishing who read her book first. Charlotte knows she is lucky because it is hard for anyone to get a first novel read, no matter their age. “Every writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. In the end, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concluded.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then a guy named David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went up the ramp quickly and flew into the air, but something looked wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said kindly, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ 

I thought maybe freestyle skiing was not for me. On past skiing holidays, I enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I was not like the teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid of looking silly if I tried to join them. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students jumped and tried their new tricks, landing in foam pits – not a real introduction to skiing outside. 

After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their skills. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ Gareth explained. ‘But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope goes down to the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which is safer. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important.

At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs wanted to slow down, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday, I felt tired. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. 

On the second day, we started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, looking at the snowy mountains, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises copied the moves we would do while ski-jumping, and others helped us learn ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what our bodies were doing while spinning in the air. Gareth gave us tips. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before jumping and then found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline.

We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes before I finally landed correctly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of my achievement. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I made myself keep my speed up as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed in the right spot. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty from fear, and you hold tightly to the safety harness. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly goes up. Then, there is a quick drop, and your stomach feels like it is in the air. You move fast, turning left and then upside down. You feel scared and let out a loud scream. But you chose to be there, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks.

It is interesting that amusement parks, with their exciting rides, are a big business. To create the thrills that people want, there are many teams of engineers and designers working behind the scenes. They make sure the rides are fun but also safe. The job of a rollercoaster designer might sound like something a child would dream of, but it is actually very challenging. Designers must find the right mix of excitement and safety while also making the rides new and interesting.

Many people think that rollercoasters are getting more extreme, but most of the ideas used today were created by a designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. Back then, there were fewer safety rules, and some rides were very scary for passengers. Now, designers have to follow the rules set by ride manufacturers.

I talked to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a "thrill engineer," said that the skill is in putting all the parts together. Dr. John Roberts explained that it is important to quickly switch between feelings of excitement and safety so that riders feel thrilled but not scared. 

To create an amazing ride, the teams must come up with a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, that goes well with the ride's features, such as height and twists. Professor Walker mentioned that, like in many creative jobs, experience and testing are very important. Jeff Hornick, a senior director in theme park development, said that it helps to love thrills when designing rollercoasters to understand what riders want.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers will use new technology, like virtual reality. Walker said we should not expect too much from it. He explained that while new technology can make rides more exciting, the real experience of being on a rollercoaster will always be the most important part for many years to come.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has done a lot as a choreographer. She has created dances for many theatres and dance companies, and she still dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both things with her busy schedule. She says, "Dancing again reminds me of being in the studio and following the orders of strict choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers sometimes forget what it’s like to rehearse all day."

As a choreographer, Miranda teaches and enjoys working with young students. She explains, "New dancers are often open to trying new ideas. Working with students can be easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they don’t always know their strengths and weaknesses. This makes them open to even tough criticism. Sometimes they challenge what I say, but I appreciate their honest feedback."

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. She says, "There might be music I don’t like, but I still try to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece of music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I wish I could be more experimental and change the music when things get tough in rehearsals. But now, I usually work on big productions where the music is already decided."

Miranda believes in meeting new people and not sticking to one place. She says, "It’s important to make connections, but I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to adapt my way of working each time I go somewhere new, so I don’t get stuck in my ways."

We talk about a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says, "Some past documentaries looked glamorous but were not true. This one shows real life in a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that feeling. She knows she’s not doing it right but can’t make her body do what she needs. It’s hard to watch, but it’s real. People often underestimate the hard work and dedication in ballet."

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. She replies, "It’s when everything comes together – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. Perfection is hard to achieve, but aiming high is important. It helps you get away with some mistakes. I’ve been in productions where the dance was great, but the costumes or props were distracting, and that’s disappointing."

Miranda has done many different types of work, so I ask if she sees herself as a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist. She says, "People like to label you, but I don’t understand why. There’s a trend to focus on one area of expertise, but I don’t follow that. Maybe one day I will be known for one thing, but for now, I want to explore more."

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that there are amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my crazy four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. 

A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to carry it. I put my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. 

I have walked on many trips in recent years, but this was very different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads. This allowed me to stop at roadside cafés and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of sitting on a rock with my sandwiches blowing away in the wind. 

I often told people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England instead of talking about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I told him I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would join ten others to swim around the small islands. He still looked confused, but he smiled and showed me on board.

Before we started, our group had exchanged emails, but there was not much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us that a support boat would be with us the whole time and showed us how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first long swim of 1.5 km. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swum in rivers, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The next days followed a routine: jumping in, swimming at a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the beautiful views. As the swims got longer, I also got faster and enjoyed them more. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat much anymore. I can’t wait to come back again next year!

Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it has many rewards. Since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have a lot of free time, and my life is always interesting. This makes it a great job for someone young like me!

When I was a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family. I often flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to the passengers. Some of them let me help. This experience stayed in my mind when I wanted to change from my banking job and look for something new.

At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people, and many of them were hired. They were often very qualified, just like me, and were also changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my skills and past work experience, not just my love for travel, which everyone else would say. Because of this, I got the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because there are many good things about it. The free flights are nice, but they are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: "No one is finished until everyone is finished." It feels like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close.

When I am not working, I don’t have to take my work home. If I do have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy seeing the children do things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel nervous at first, but with some encouragement, they try and eventually reach the top. This makes them feel very happy.

At the start of the week, some children miss their homes. It is not the younger ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We do not let them use their mobile phones all the time. We tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again after dinner, we say it is too late to call and that they can do it tomorrow. Most children feel better after a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they come to us and thank us because they had a great time.

Sometimes, it is not just the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who call a lot to ask how their child is doing, which is not really needed. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to tell the parents to call back later.

We also see some children who come dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it is important.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, it was challenging to do the show with an all-British cast. In the UK, there are more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night. Everyone wants to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He talked about how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ 

I asked Jamie what his classmates thought of the show. He said, ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket prices for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them.’ When I told Jamie that I also play guitar, he found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! 

Even though the young actors were already musicians and some played several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
